title: Ticket #5021: Missing RPM dependencies in condor-static-shadow
description:
The condor-static-shadow package currently ships the 32-bit shadow on all platforms (on purpose - the whole point of the package is to have the smallest possible footprint).

However, because we currently dlopen libvomsapi, the RPM auto-dependency detection doesn't pick up the 32-bit VOMS as a dependency. For the main package, libvomsapi is brought in directly as some daemons link directly.

This makes for a broken out-of-the-box experience.

CC'ing Jaime on this ticket in case he can think of other dlopened libraries that should be explicitly included.
remarks:
2015-Apr-27 08:20:19 by bbockelm:
Actually, there's a few other curiosities:
  • 8.3.4 and before both provided and required the various globus libraries. The 'provided' part caused serious heartache at sites because it doesn't actually place the embedded Globus libraries in the linker's search path.
  • 8.3.5 no longer 'provides' the globus libraries, but still requires them. That means installing this on RHEL will pull in system globus, no?
  • The new condor-static-shadow package can't really be used "UW-style"; the libraries it needs are in the 32-bit condor RPM. You need to split out the libs (and make it multiarch); in the meantime, CMS will just install the system RPMs such as VOMS.

2015-Apr-27 10:32:42 by jfrey:
The Globus and VOMS libraries are still provided, but are now in a separate condor-externals package. They're required only if you want to do GSI authentication. So maybe the 32-bit condor-externals package should be required by the condor-all package, but probably not by the condor-static-shadow directly.

The other libraries that could be dlopen'd by the static shadow are those for Kerberos.

2015-Apr-27 14:58:39 by bbockelm:
Hm - another curiosity; within condor-externals: 

/usr/libexec/condor/glite/share/doc/glite-ce-blahp-@PVER@/LICENSE

I'm guessing a variable didn't get expanded?

Given how the RPM world usually take an expansive view of dependencies, we should probably add an explicit dependency on libvomsapi. Just like with the main condor package, we can let the yum depsolver pick whether to take it from the system or the UW repos.

2015-Apr-29 09:00:38 by bbockelm:
Hi,

You can't install condor-externals.i686 side-by-side with condor-externals.x86_64 because there are conflicting files (binaries in /usr/libexec/condor/glite/bin; shell scripts are OK as long as the md5sum is the same for both 64-bit and 32-bit versions).

Further, condor-externals has a dependency on condor; definitely can't have both the 32-bit and 64-bit version of the condor binaries on a single host!

Can someone else reproduce? Unfortunately, I think this really makes condor-shadow-static difficult to use in this release.

Finally - while we're fixing packaging - if condor-shadow-static is installed, can we drop a file in /etc/condor/config.d to set:

SHADOW=$(SBIN)/condor_shadow_s

?

Thanks,

Brian

2015-Apr-29 10:13:02 by tim:
We are running the 32-bit static shadow in CHTC. So, the VOMS and globus libraries are optional. If you want to use those, you would have to load the 32-bit externals. However, as you have noticed there are conflicts and dependencies that need to be addressed for this to work.

So, I think that we need to be able to load the 32-bit externals alongside the 64-bit externals. I also think that the static shadow should not require the externals, since it work when you don't need those optional features it works just fine.

Would it be worthwhile to run the 64-bit static shadow?

2015-May-13 15:27:51 by edquist:
I just had a thought about [44839] --

I get the problem with the static-shadow, that requiring the main condor package effectively makes it impossible to install the 32bit one with the 64bit condor,

BUT, without it, is there anything that keeps versions (NVRs, if not Arches) in sync? I think the answer might be No, but correct me if I'm wrong. Same issue/question for external-libs, which doesn't appear to be required by name (or NVR) by any other sub-packages.

It might work to install the first time around but I think afterwards it might be possible to yum update condor and then the versions of static-shadow and external-libs get out of sync (ie, not get upgraded along with the rest of condor).

That is, of course, the other reason to have a Requires: %{name} = %{version}-%{release} -- if not because it's required by the sub-package, then at least to keep the versions in sync.

... Can we whip something up, possibly with a virtual Provides, that we can use to keep the versions in sync without necessarily requiring the main condor package of the same arch?

2015-May-13 16:05:06 by bbockelm:
What about having: 

Requires: %{name} = %{version}

in the condor-static-shadow package? That will keep the major version in sync without requiring the same arch.

2015-May-14 09:59:13 by tim:
That is what we had in the first place. But in CHTC, Moate was having problems downgrading with yum when this dependency on the parent was in place. So, let's give what we have not a try.

2015-May-14 12:48:35 by edquist:
Hi Tim,

From what I see in [44839], it used to be:

Requires: %{name} = %version-%release

But Brian is suggesting dropping the %release part:

Requires: %{name} = %{version}

Which of the two was causing problems in CHTC?

2015-May-15 18:40:23 by edquist:
Actually... After thinking about this a little more,

Requires: %name = %version-%release

shouldn't require the same arch (I did some tests that agree), and further, I suspect the downgrade problems seen in CHTC will happen regardless of mixed-arch setups -- you need to make sure to 'yum downgrade' all the condor packages (that depend on each other) at the same time by listing them all on the command line together, otherwise the downgrade will fail...

So my guess is the Requires: %name = %version-%release can stay for the static-shadow without causing trouble ... The real issue was just with the dependencies for externals (or now external-libs), right?
